urn:contentItem:5RCY-12M1-JB20-G0YC-00000-00Ford Motor Co at JP Morgan CES Tech Forum - Final2018-01-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:31ZLexisNexis010918a11186536.736Ford Motor Coat JP Morgan CES Tech Forum - Final

Corporate Participants

* Hau Thai-Tang

Conference Call Participants

* Ryan J. Brinkman

JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division - Senior Equity Research Analyst

Presentation

RYAN J. BRINKMAN, SENIOR EQUITY RESEARCH ANALYST, JP MORGAN CHASE & CO, RESEARCH DIVISION: Okay. I thank you for joining us today. Very happy to have Ford Motor Companyat this conference for the first time and happy to have Hau Thai-Tang here. Hau, thanks for coming. Hau is the Executive Vice President of Product Development and Purchasing for Ford Motor Company. He has, I was just mentioning, almost precisely the same title as the next speaker from General Motors. It'd be nice to compare their responses. Welcome.

Questions and Answers

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: I think maybe just to begin, you've spent 25 years in various roles, often in product development, right? And given that perspective, I was just curious, from an overarching perspective, if you could share a little bit about how the auto industry has evolved over that period of time in terms of its focus on technology, like how would you rate the pace of innovation today, for example, compared to prior periods, et cetera?

HAU THAI-TANG: Thanks, Ryan. Thanks for having us, and thanks, everybody, for your interest in Ford. As Ryan mentioned, I'm approaching 30 years with Ford. I spent the first 25 in product development, the last 4 in purchasing, and now I have a chance to work with both teams. And the rate of innovation is just really astounding right now and it's more than just the pace of innovation. I think you have this confluence of changing consumer behaviors, a lot of that fueled by millennials and younger buyers but also by technology, and the smart car being a great example. You have this convergence of advances in technologies, connectivity, autonomy, electrification. And all of these things are really profound changes that can kind of -- a pretty dramatic impact on how we think about not only the design of the vehicles in terms of the architecture, but the value creation and how we're going to differentiate ourselves in the marketplace, and then on top of that, you've got business model innovation. So the combination of all those things together is creating this disruptive force, and it's something that's really unprecedented in the 115-year history of Ford Motor Company.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: Thanks for that overview. I'm just curious the different roles that you do have, at product development and purchasing. Can you talk about how these roles, seemingly different, actually might be sort of hand in hand and how that can drive improvements in the product and cost?

HAU THAI-TANG: Yes. This is clearly one of the, I think, motivations behind combining the 2 organizations under 1 leader, with Jim Hackett coming onboard, as we really see -- historically, this is something our suppliers have cited that Ford has done very well, having this -- we refer to it as a matched pair concept, where we have write-downs at the engineer-buyer level, all the way up through the senior executives, a matched pair between product development and purchasing. Now having them under 1 organization is just going to accelerate this. And it gives us a chance to think about commodity segmentation, how we want to determine which parts are core to Ford that we should do ourselves in-house, both the design and, in some cases, the manufacturing, to what should we leverage our supplier partners for and how do we want to engage them and at what point in time. And if we can do that well, we'll not only deliver more technology and innovation to the marketplace, but do it at much greater value for the customers.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: What does that decision-making framework look like, in terms of do you develop a capability in-house versus you try to outsource it from suppliers?

HAU THAI-TANG: Yes. We -- just like most things, we start with a customer point of view, and we try to think about how does the customers see value in that particular commodity, system, technology and is it going to be brand differentiating for Ford going forward. And I think this is something that's going to change very dramatically. It is changing very dramatically in the marketplace. Some of the things that historically had been brand differentiating I don't think will be going forward in a world that's increasingly more connected, autonomous and electrified. So we start with that point of view, and then we think about what's the value-add that Ford can bring? Is it a good use of capital? Is it a good use of engineering resources? And then if the answer to those questions are yes, then those are things that we would potentially do ourselves and vertically integrate, and if the answer is no, then we would most likely look to partner or to leverage our supplier partners to do that.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: The investors here who participated in the last presentation heard a lot about connected cars. Aptiv was the speaker there. And I'm just curious how the increasingly connected nature of cars might affect your job in terms of product development.

HAU THAI-TANG: It's completely changed the way we think about the product. Once the vehicles become connected to the Internet of Things, it's a completely different ball game in terms of value creation, services that we can provide, how the customers think about the products, the ability -- we started seeing this maybe a decade ago, when people started bringing nomadic devices, their own phones, tablets into the vehicles. But now, having vehicles with modems and then having them connected and being able to communicate to the vehicles even when the driver is not in the car is game-changing. So this is something that is a huge part of our focus in terms of smart vehicles in a smart world. It's a big part of how we want to differentiate Ford going forward, and it's requiring us to really think about the entire vehicle differently in terms of the electrical architecture. So I'll give you an example. Almost every single Ford and Lincoln vehicle in the U.S. comes with a garage door opener. We also have GPS in all of our cars. So you should be able to geofence it and have it recognized when it's pulling up to your driveway and automatically open the garage door. All of those -- a lot of garage door openers now are smart devices that are connected. But to do that, you have to rewire the electrical architecture of the vehicle to get those stand-alone devices to talk to each other, and so that's something we would partner with a company like Aptiv to do, yes.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: And I'm curious, too, in your focus on product development, you've come up with some really strong years, record and near-record years for light vehicle sales in the U.S. It's been a very significant trend there, right, where the passenger car segment of those sales has been really declining while the crossovers and the trucks have been increasing. I'm just curious what your thoughts are in terms of the future of passenger cars in the U.S. and what that means in terms of ability to profit and how much resources you allocate toward that effort.

HAU THAI-TANG: Yes. So I wouldn't want to generalize because one of our learnings from -- as we transition beyond ONE Ford is not to just think about all segments and markets as being homogeneous. We have some passenger cars that do really well, that are very -- that are profitable. Mustang is a great example. And I think in the luxury segment, some of those passenger vehicles also can be very profitable and differentiated. But there are segments, primarily B, C, C, D in the U.S. market, that are becoming commoditized. People in those market in -- shopping in those segments are looking for low total cost of ownership, reliability, resale value, and those are things that maybe are not historical strengths and hallmarks of Ford. So as we go through and look at our business of where we compete, where we allocate capital, where do we allocate engineering resources, we consider all of those things. The shift that you've highlighted of going into crossovers and utility vehicles, we think, is a secular shift. We don't see this as a trend. And I think people -- once they make the move, they like the higher command driving position, the greater visibility, the sense of confidence, the utility of those vehicles, and the vehicles are getting increasingly better for fuel efficiency because of the pace of -- the regulatory requirements are outpacing the cost of fuel. That customers, I don't think, will go back even if the price of gas goes up. So we see this as a secular shift, but I don't want to generalize across all markets and all segments.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: Yes. Pivoting then, though, from cars to trucks, which are a historical hallmark and strength of Ford Motor Company. I think there's going to be some new competition in 2018 with maybe a new Ram, maybe a new Silverado and Sierra. I just -- can you talk about what you're doing to keep the F-Series, the best-selling vehicle, fresh and competitive amidst that increased competition?

HAU THAI-TANG: Yes. We -- it's a very competitive business that we're in, and that segment, in particular, is increasingly more competitive as you've highlighted, Ryan. I think what we've done really well and why we've been the best-selling vehicle and the best-selling truck for over 40 years is we understand those customers very well. We don't rest on our laurels. So as you guys all know, we did a major change, architectural change in 2015. And then 3 years later, we followed up with a very significant freshening, all-new powertrain lineup. We just launched this year -- or we just announced that we're going to launch a diesel engine into the F-150, and all of those things are geared to deliver to those truck customers what they want, which is not only improved fuel efficiency, but more capability, more towing, more payload, things that they value and they want to pay for. It's funny that you bring this up because immediately after Jim's keynote this morning, I had the honor to accept one of the Edmunds CES innovation awards. F-150 was named the Most Innovative Truck of CES, and this is coming off earlier this year where it was named Motor Trend Truck of the Year. So it just shows you that we're not resting on our laurels, and we're committing to continue to invest in that product to keep it ahead.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: I think I saw a headline the other day saying that the diesel in the F-150 might break like 30 miles per gallon, so like the 4-minute mile for pickup trucks. Is that possible?

HAU THAI-TANG: Thirty-mile per gallon on a highway, yes. That's a really significant milestone. It's also based on the SAE calculations. It's going to deliver Best-in-class Towing and Payload as well.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: Speaking of powertrains, I think an important or an interesting question is, what is the most advantageous type of power train for autonomous vehicles? GM has been pretty adamant recently that all AVs must be EVs, but Delphi and some others have said that maybe plug-in hybrid would lend itself better because you wouldn't have to take vehicles out of service. So utilization could be greater. I'm just curious -- and then also, is there a power draw or a range draw from all of the technologies that facilitate autonomous? Where does -- what's Ford's current thinking in terms of this debate?

HAU THAI-TANG: Yes. I think the answer to this question really depends on the time horizon of which you're talking about. Are you talking about 10 years from now, 20 years from now or 3 or 4 years from now? I think we -- when we talk about, I'll call it, the near-term horizon, when these vehicles start to launch, they will be very expensive vehicles, these autonomous vehicles. We're talking LiDAR systems that are in the tens of thousands of dollars. Now we know with technology and scale, the cost will come down. But I think we can all fairly say that the first generation of autonomous vehicles are going to be very expensive assets. If you have an expensive asset, if it's not being utilized, you're not making money. So that's a very simplistic way to look at it. And for us, offering our customers the ability to have maximized uptime is going to be very key. That's why we think a hybrid solution is the ideal solution. The power draw consumptions of the sensors and the computational hardware in the vehicles, if you look at most companies and all of the leading companies, they'll tell you it's somewhere between 3- to 4-kilowatt hour -- kilowatt per hour. So on a 20-hour cycle, that's 60 kilowatts. That's the range of most electric vehicles. So we don't think, in the near term, that, that complete BEV vehicle is going to give you the utilization that will deliver the cost of ownership that those customers will demand. Now you can argue that you [won't] get advances in computational powers. The sensors will demand less current draw. All those things are absolutely true, but you have -- as technologists, as development engineers, you have to work with the current state sensor suites to develop the systems. So we can talk about, and if common, what's going to happen 10 or 20 years from now. But in the near term, we don't think a BEV will deliver the best solution for those customers.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: I see. And not long ago, speaking of BEVs, you announced a partnership with a domestic Chinese automaker. I believe it's pronounced Zotye.

HAU THAI-TANG: Zotye.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: A couple of different pronunciations. Can you talk a little bit about the motivations behind that partnership, what it says about your strategy to grow in China, what kind of powertrain types might be in that country? And it's also no secret that automakers have struggled to make a profit on electric vehicles, right? How might this partnership help along those lines?

HAU THAI-TANG: Yes. I think all of those things are key considerations. First, we have to recognize that the markets are differentiated because of the regulatory environment, the cost of fuel and the consumer behavior. Certainly, China, there's a very strong push from the government to drive new energy vehicles. Clearly, part of that push is to drive localization of the entire value chain, so not only the vehicles themselves, but also the battery manufacturing, the raw materials, the supply chain. And we look at where the growth is happening and where the incentives are being offered, both on the demand side as well as the supply side. The sweet spot is really going to be in the B and C segment at lower cost, and that's typically not an area where the global western OEMs have done a very strong job of. So we're still going to go to market with Ford and Lincoln electrified vehicles in China. But to get the level of penetration and scale that we need, we need a local partner that has the expertise, the value chain, the supply base that's localized that can compete in that high volume, lower revenue price band. So we've been delighted. It's great learning for us as well in terms of how can we increase our cost competitiveness in China, not just for battery electric vehicles but across the entire portfolio. And it gives us a chance to partner and build local scale, develop new indigenous suppliers and find solutions that are better suited for those local Chinese customers.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: I think around the same time as you announced that partnership, there was also something in the works with Mahindra, is that right? What were you trying to gain from that relationship in terms of development of vehicles?

HAU THAI-TANG: Yes. We've announced a memorandum of understanding with Mahindra in India just to explore ways for us to both improve our business in India. India is -- while it's a big market with tremendous growth opportunities, it is a market that is very tough on costs, very low revenue. And for us to compete there, we really need to understand the Indian customer requirements better. Mahindra is somebody who's been very successful in that market. Their product portfolio, I think, potentially complement ours very well, and we can help them in areas, such as electrification and some powertrain technology, as the regulatory environment changes. So it's something that we're having a lot of fruitful dialogue on, yes.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: Okay. And you talked before about sort of the question of whether AVs must be EVs. But independent of that, must AVs be connected cars? It seems like 5 years ago at CES, all anyone wanted to talk about relative to the (inaudible) was connectivity, and now it's more autonomous. But I was just curious looking in product development to the extent to which you see these 2 trends as interrelated.

HAU THAI-TANG: Yes. I don't -- so you may get some debates on whether or not AVs have to be BEVs. So EVs is too general because we are aligned that a hybrid is good solution. But you won't get anybody, I don't think, that will debate whether or not AVs have to be connected. That's mandatory, clearly, for route planning and telematics and all those things. But I think even going beyond that, as we see advances in artificial intelligence, edge computing, how much of that can you now do, how much of that processing can you do off board of the vehicle. And leverage the infrastructure and the cloud, I think, will be a huge enabler to reduce power consumption, drive the cost down and potentially make it compatible with a BEV architecture. So those are all things that I think everybody's aligned on.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: The CEO Strategy Update back in the fall, Ford outlined some really aggressive cost-saving objectives. And it was discussed that the cost savings will build and be much larger in the out-year than initially, and the explanation that was given to that was we want to cut a lot of material cost and it's a lot easier to do that as we entirely develop a vehicle from scratch, some big cost savings targets. It seems like the organization is going to be looking for a lot from you in terms of your ability to reduce material costs and purchasing. Can you just give us some outlines in terms of how you expect to deliver those savings?

HAU THAI-TANG: Sure, yes. I think, Ryan, what you're referring to is Jim Hackett referenced a $14 billion cost opportunity over the planned period versus what we had in our plan. So it's a variance from a plan that we had. $10 billion of the $14 billion is going to come out of material costs, which is basically the cost that goes into every vehicle that we design and purchase, and then the remaining $4 billion would come out of engineering costs. So I feel sorry for the guy that's got to deliver both those things.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: That would be you.

HAU THAI-TANG: That would -- that's me. So on material cost, it's really -- it's a couple of things. It's leveraging our understanding that the customers are learning from ONE Ford analytics, now that we have better -- a lot more data coming off the vehicles, understanding what customers use, what features and technologies and then selectively putting in the right content that customers value that they want to pay for is a huge opportunity. This opportunity of PD and purchasing working with the supply base earlier, I think, is another huge opportunity. A big one for me is, we touched on the theme earlier, is rethinking how we're going to differentiate Ford and Lincoln going forward in the future, and in the areas where we no longer think they're going to be differentiated, is how do we stop spending money in those areas. So all of those things are things that we're all looking at. Regulatory costs is a huge part of the cost adds. It was in the original plan. One of the things we're doing a much better job of is having a better expectation of how scale advances in technology should drive the cost down. I'll give you a great example. When we launched EcoBoost more than a decade ago, we had 1 turbocharger supplier. We started with BorgWarner. Now we have 4. We've developed Honeywell, Continental, MAHLE. So we've driven down the design costs, but we've also driven down the commercial costs through greater scale, but also more competition in the marketplace. So what's our expectation of how the costs of the EcoBoost engines, how did that come down over time? How would you then extrapolate that to other technologies, such as rear cameras or automatic braking, all the things that we're being forced at into the vehicle, stop/start systems. So we're overlaying some of those things in -- as in the enabler for the $10 billion. On the $4 billion of engineering costs, it's just improving our engineering efficiency, reducing complexity, which Jim talked about, speeding up time to market and leveraging some of our joint venture partners.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: I have more questions for Tau but -- for Hau, but are there any in the audience? One up front. Why don't you speak loudly? Sorry, yes.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Can you just talk to the (inaudible) so which is some of the big tech companies, such as Google, now you've got (inaudible) there, as well. You've got Apple as well. How does Ford think about their role versus some of the big tech players as it comes to the consumer experience in the car? And how does Ford end up owning that experience versus some of the other tech players?

HAU THAI-TANG: Yes. So the question was really around the integrating some of the technologies into the vehicle and what does Ford view as ours versus others. I think a great example is what you'll hear this week. We're going to announce a partnership with Waze, and this is one where I know from personal experience. I drive a Lincoln Continental. This is our flagship luxury vehicle with all the latest technology. It's got a wonderful instrument cluster in it, all sorts of technology. And the first thing I do when I get in is I put my Waze on my iPhone and I stick it in front of my 12-inch cluster. Why? Because it works better for navigation, and it's crowd-sourced. It tells me where the police are hiding and I find value in that. I don't think I'm atypical. So for us, that's a great example of, is that something that Ford should invest engineering and capital to do or should we integrate Waze and have -- leverage that network effect of the crowd-sourcing of the Wazers into our vehicles? We're electing to do the latter. So we're doing -- you'll see us do more and more of that. You referenced Amazon Alexa integration. That's another thing. But as we do those things, we're also being very clear around who owns the data, what part is Ford's, what information is captured in the vehicle with our GPS system versus the smartphone in the case of Waze and then how do we monetize that? So that's very core in terms of our thinking.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: Any other questions from the audience? One up front.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Can you talk about the 48-volt opportunities? Would you say, is that significant?

HAU THAI-TANG: It is significant. It's more significant in Europe. It tends to be a solution that's a better CO2 buy and CO2 reduction as a dollar buy for the driving cycle, the certification cycle in Europe. Smaller displacement engine as well as with manual transmissions, so we're going very heavy in terms of proliferating 48-volt systems in Europe. In the U.S., with the U.S. SORT cycles, the larger displacement engines and the higher penetration of automatic transmission, we don't see it as good of a weight buy -- fuel economy buy.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: I wanted to ask how you balance in your job as head of product development to seemingly competing objectives. I mean, on the one hand, you want vehicles to be common and global. So the focus is the same in China as the U.S. as in Brazil, so that you can drive development and purchasing synergies. And then on the other hand, people have different tastes, different cultural preferences and needs in different markets. How do you balance those 2 competing interests? Are they not competing? How do you think about that?

HAU THAI-TANG: They are, at times, competing and I think this is probably one of our biggest learnings from ONE Ford, where we have to evolve our thinking, and it gets back to understanding the customers and what they want. And if the customers want the same things, then there's a huge opportunity for us to go to market with 1 global solution and not engineer it multiple times and leverage the global scale. But we're finding in markets like India, going back to our earlier discussion, those customers want very different things than the customers driving on the autobahn in Cologne, where we do a lot of our B car and C car engineering. So we have to really think through that, the customer lens on what they value. We're also finding that localization is becoming increasingly important, either because it's a requirement to get tax and tariff avoidance or it just makes sense as an exchange rate hedge. So if you have to localize with a local supplier, in the past, we typically would incentivize global suppliers to go invest and invest in brick-and-mortar in these far-flung regions. And there, we're finding that, that's not always the best way to get the best value. You're better off working with an Indian supplier versus asking your global suppliers to go into India because what we found is oftentimes, they'll say I -- that's not where I want to spend my capital. I'd rather put another plant in Mexico or China. I'll go to India if you want me to, but you're going to pay a premium for me to do that. So we're not realizing the savings. So I tell my team all the time, there's not a lot of sense in having a lot of scale of a design that's too expensive for that market, right? So what we're doing is -- as a combined team now, product development and purchasing, is for each commodity really thinking through how does the customer think about it? Is it truly a commodity that you can market test and source to the lowest bidder or is it something that's much more engineering investment intensive that you want 1 global partner to work with? And there's everything in between. How do we think through that as a company?

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: Are there any more questions in the audience? It looks like there are several. [Paritosh]?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. Just 2 quick ones. First, on the buy side, can you speak to what you're seeing with all the commodity inflation we've seen over the last 6 to 12 months, as far as how you guys go about procuring and the lead time lag associated with that? And the second, are you able to comment at all on product development and where they are with introducing or sharing their development work with [the customer].

HAU THAI-TANG: Argo AI?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes.

HAU THAI-TANG: Yes. So on the first question, we are still seeing some headwinds around commodities. What we try to do is really manage and mitigate those headwinds by staggering our contracts. So for example, when we buy steel or aluminum, we tend to stagger the contracts across the different suppliers that we work with so that they don't all expire at the same time. They're typically staggered by 6 months. That gives us a little bit of a hedge in terms of what's the month-to-month, week-to-week volatility in the commodity prices. And then obviously, we do our best to do substitution where we can and then improve utilization, but -- versus we had a tremendous windfall in commodity prices the year prior. And this year, we're just seeing the other side of it, and we're still seeing and anticipating some headwinds there. As you guys know, currency in many markets are tied directly to commodity prices. So there's also -- when we think about it, we also think about what's happening in the currency and there's a natural hedge there as well in terms of the cost basis. So it's not fair just to look only at commodities. On Argo AI, they're making great progress. I think you'll hear them talk more externally this year around some of the objectives and key milestones that they're achieving. We're very confident in that investment that we've made, that it's the right thing to do for us to accelerate our vision of delivering autonomous vehicles to market.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: I think we have time for just 1 more question in the front here.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: So today, I mean, there are probably like 20 of (inaudible) driving platform in the marketplace. Each OEM has their own kind of a platform. Each big tech company has their own. But if you look like -- I mean, in the future, in Asia and in Europe, I don't think there will be a like a 20-platform environment. So what do you think of the competitive landscape is going to evolve, in like a long term? Who will be the winner? How many platform would be (inaudible)?

HAU THAI-TANG: Yes. I think -- again, you have to differentiate, are we talking about Level 2, Level 3 or Level 4 autonomy? And even that as a definition, I think is too -- it's not granular enough. So there's a big difference in Level 3 at -- are we talking below 40 miles an hour or above 55 miles an hour? Are we talking divided highway or non-divided highway? So the -- I can speak to what Ford is doing. We believe for Level 4 autonomy, there's ride-hailing and goods movement that Jim Farley and Jim Hackett talked about earlier, this -- controlling the thinking phase, the algorithm for the virtual driving system is going to be core to Ford and brand differentiating, and that's something that we want to develop with partnership with Argo AI. And I think like most things, initially, you'll have a lot of competitors, but it will -- your premise is correct. You'll see consolidation and it will probably be down to a handful of players in that space, once they start getting into markets. Most likely, the solutions in China, because of the regulatory and national security concerns, will be different than solutions in other markets. So you may have to double the number of players if you include China versus Western Europe and North America. Level 3 and Level 2, I think this is clearly going to be in the domain of the supply base. You guys just walked out of Aptiv. They're one of the big players. There's other people: the Continentals and DENSOs and Boschs of the world that are all involved, and I anticipate that they'll be probably half a dozen very strong players, if not more, in that space as well.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: Very interesting. That's all the time we have today, but please join me in thanking Hau for coming to the conference.

HAU THAI-TANG: Thank you.

RYAN J. BRINKMAN: Thank you. Really appreciate it, nice insights.

urn:contentItem:5HV2-5HH1-JCMN-Y3N0-00000-00Ford spells out the future of electric, autonomous, and smart cars2016-01-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:31ZLexisNexisFord spells out the future of electric, autonomous, and smart carsDean Takahashi

Jan 11, 2016( VentureBeat: http://venturebeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Ford plans to launch 13 electric vehicles[1] by 2020 (a $4 billion investment) and is creating its own fleet of research vehicles that will be able to drive themselves. The modern car company sees itself as not just a part of the $2.3 trillion auto industry, where it has a 6 percent market share, but as a member of the $5.4 trillion transportation market. We attended Ford's press event at CES, the big tech trade show[2] in Las Vegas last week. At the event, Ford CEO Mark Fields said the company would triple the number of autonomous vehicles it is testing and adopt Velodyne's solid-state hybrid Ultra Puck auto sensor for precision mapping. Ford is partnering with drone maker DJI to develop drone-to-vehicle technology for emergency services. And it is also working on ways that you can send voice commands to your car to get its motor running in the morning. After the press event, we sat down with Don Butler, executive director of Ford's connected vehicles and services, in an interview. Here's an edited transcript of our conversation.

http://venturebeat.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/DSCN0106.jpg Above: Ford CEO Mark Fields at CES 2016. Image Credit: Dean Takahashi VentureBeat: If you have a bunch of electric vehicles coming, what sort of percentage of the whole is that, and at what time? Don Butler: Electric vehicles, for us, represent a means of attaining some of the efficiency requirements we have. Either fully or partially electrified vehicles will represent up to a quarter of our lineup within the next five or so years. Now, part of that will depend on consumer appetite for those vehicles. We have to make sure that they're desirable, that they meet consumer expectations. Also, when we look at fuel prices, we need to make sure we get, at least within the U.S., the chance for the government to reassess the standards and understand what's feasible. We can make [the cars], but we need people to buy them. VB: On autonomous vehicles, some people thought you were going to talk more about Google and some kind of alliance? Butler: Did they? [laughs] Not sure why they'd have that opinion. We work with a number of partners, as our CEO has described, underneath this umbrella we call Fort Smart Mobility. Whether you're talking connectivity, or some of the mobility experiments and services we're looking at, the overall customer experience — We used to say our customers' digital lifestyles are connected lifestyles. That's understood now in autonomous driving and big data and analytics. We recognize that we will need to work with partners in the space, because as we look at the vehicle as more than just a piece of hardware that moves you from A to B, we're increasingly looking at the vehicle as a platform for the delivery of services. Some of those services we'll be able to deliver end to end. Financing. That's a good example. Ford Credit, we can do financing for you. Other services we'll connect with partners that are already developing their own ecosystems. We'll take advantage of that development without having to do it. What we're doing with Amazon is a good example. Amazon, the Eco device, and the Alexa cloud platform, they're already in the home, in many homes. They're already connecting with other smart things in the home. Rather than us stitching together that network, why don't we partner with someone who already is putting that network together and create a way of seamlessly interacting with them? When we look at autonomous vehicles, we've been working on that for more than a decade. It's not as if we need a partner to come help us. We are open to working with partners together to create autonomous vehicles, but it's not a situation where we become a contract manufacturer for someone. We talk about news when it's ready to be talked about. What you saw today, we talked about our partnership with Velodyne, our work with the University of Michigan. We're continuing to advance on the autonomous front. As developments occur, we'll be sure to communicate about those. <nl/>Play Video[3] VB: I've read a bit about some of the challenges for self-driving cars. I wonder what you think is the state of things in that field, how far the research has gotten. Butler: The research has advanced quite a bit. That's one reason we've moved from the pure research phase to what we call the 'advanced engineering phase.' The pure research phase is one around just feasibility. Is it feasible to have a car drive itself? Now we're in a stage where we've proven that. Now the question is, how would you implement it? That's why we're expanding our fleet, moving from about 10 vehicles to about 30. The bulk of that fleet will be in the Michigan area. A lot of that work will be at Em City, at our own proving grounds in Dearborn. Some of that work will be in California. We recently announced that we've received a license to operate autonomous vehicles in California. The technical side is coming along really well. The thing we need to work on is continuing to refine the algorithms and our sensor technology. You see an example of that with Velodyne, working with them to shrink the size of the LIDAR [Light Detection and Ranging] sensor. Our goal is what we call level four autonomy, which is fully autonomous, driver out of the loop, but only in known geographic locations and known conditions. That's what we're aiming for. From a technical standpoint it's very much within reach, within the next four years. What we need to work on at the same time are some of the regulatory and liability issues. Some of the societal issues in terms of autonomous vehicles interacting with vehicles that are being driven. It's a situation where the landscape continues to evolve. We're evolving and adapting with it. We're focusing on the technical challenges and working with other partners, like universities and governments, on the regulatory, liability, and societal sides.   http://venturebeat.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/ford-ceo.jpg Above: Ford CEO Mark Fields says people searching for parking cause 30% of congestion. Image Credit: Ford VB: Things like LIDAR, are they the likely path for tackling that problem? Butler: From the exposure I've had, LIDAR and its ability to, first of all, do 360 degrees, and then the ability to do precise 3D mapping -That's critical. And then for the vehicle to have a really clear sense of where it is within that environment. We think you can't just rely on cameras or radar or other sensors. We think it's a combination of all of those that's going to be necessary. One of the challenges is those unanticipated or unexpected things. It's fairly easy to map a static environment, and even to map the roadway and expectations of what happens on it. There's no way to map pedestrian behavior, or the behavior of the bicyclist right next to you and what happens if they don't obey a stop sign. Encountering those situations and understanding the parameters that lead into that will impact and affect those deep learning algorithms. But we're all exploring similar territory. We'll be working partners where it makes sense, bringing our own knowledge and expertise to bear. VB: And then the other big problem of just waking up the human. Butler: That's why we're focusing on level four. There are two different paths happening. What we call the semi-autonomous path, levels one through three, the driver will still need to be engaged, but we're doing things to assist in the driving experience, like adaptive cruise control or panic stop braking. But we believe that when you're in autonomous, you need to be in a situation where the vehicle can drive itself. We're looking at what that means. How do you operate in a situation where you have to hand control back to the driver? That's a tough area. Other than saying, 'You need to keep your hands on the wheel.' It's interesting to look at companies like Tesla and what they're doing with autopilot. It's funny. It even says 'Beta' on the screen, and yet it's out in production. Our goal, though, and what we're working on with our autonomous fleet, is level four, driver completely out of the loop.   http://venturebeat.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/ford-ceo-2.jpg Above: Ford CEO Mark Fields has stats on how the roads are getting more congested. Image Credit: Ford VB: It still seems like the problem that Mark painted about how crowded cities are going to get isn't all that solvable with smarter things. Butler: It's certainly more addressable. The smarter things are, the more connected they are. Then we have the opportunity to do things much more efficiently - things like route-planning and logistics. We have a partnership with a fleet services company called Telogis. They work with other companies that have large fleets of vehicles. They help them manage those fleets. Most of those vehicles happen to be Fords, so we've worked with them to provide telematics capability within vehicles to do things like managing and monitoring fuel consumption, logistics planning, map pathing, and planning for those vehicles out in the market. If everything can become that much more efficient by being connected, you reduce congestion. You reduce traffic. Things become more efficient. We're also working with cities. Even our Go Drive pilot, we're working with the city of London on understanding their goals and how we can participate with them in helping to achieve those. Certainly the challenges that Mark outlined are daunting. We also recognize them. We're not hiding from them. We're taking steps to address them. The more connected our world is and the more willing we are to work with partners, I think we will find solutions. VB: Anything else you'd like to focus on? Butler: Another great example of working with partners is, again, what we're doing with Amazon. The point of this whole notion is, we understand that the vehicle is no longer just a piece of hardware that gets you from A to B. We are no longer just in the vehicle hardware business. That represents, if you saw the presentation today, $2.3 trillion of revenue. The transportation services business is $5.4 trillion. Even beyond that, the commerce that's conducted while you're traveling represents an even bigger and broader opportunity. For us it's about interacting and intersecting with those areas of opportunity and understanding how we can put enablers in place — like App Link inside our vehicles for connecting with smartphone apps - to help create this new future. The important part is, we've been around for 113 years. I think we'll be around for many more years beyond that. We've demonstrated resilience. Things that have been disrupters in the past, we've looked at as opportunities, and we look at today in a similar way. VB: It's like railroads and the transportation business. Which are you in? Butler: We're definitely in the mobility business. That's what we're in. VB: It made me think of Ford Airways, Ford Tollways… Butler: Or working with partners in those areas, for sure.   http://venturebeat.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/ford-ceo-3.jpg Above: Ford CEO Mark Fields wants to move beyond cars into transportation services. Image Credit: Ford<nl/> [ 1]:   http://venturebeat.com/2016/01/05/ford-positions-itself-as-a-high-tech-car-company-with-13-electric-cars-coming-by-2020/ [ 2]:   http://venturebeat.com/2016/01/09/the-deanbeat-the-10-best-technologies-of-the-consumer-electronics-show/ [ 3]:   https://www.youtube.com/embed/YtD5zGFLSo8?feature=oembed

urn:contentItem:5HMS-VGJ1-JCJY-G319-00000-00Ford starts testing DRIVERLESS cars in California as Google slams 'perplexing' new rules;Ford is taking on Google with its own driverless car, but is California ready for the robotic vehicles to invade its roads?2015-12-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:31ZLexisNexisNEWS,TECHNOLOGY & SCIENCE,TECHNOLOGYFord starts testing DRIVERLESS cars in California as Google slams 'perplexing' new rulesFord is taking on Google with its own driverless car, but is California ready for the robotic vehicles to invade its roads?By Sophie Curtis

It's not just whiz-bang technology companies like Google that are experimenting with driverless vehicles - traditional car companies are also jumping on the bandwagon.

Ford has announced that it will begin testing fully autonomous vehicles on Californian roads in the new year.

The company's Fusion Hybrid sedans have sensors that can detect and track objects in the vehicle's view to provide a 360-degree view of the car's surroundings - including street signs and other vehicles.

Meanwhile, camera sensors serve as the eyes of a vehicle, allowing the car to "see" and sense pedestrians.

Ford now has one of the largest automotive research centres in Silicon Valley, with more than 100 researchers, engineers and scientists on staff at its research and innovation centre in Palo Alto.

It is hoping that by getting an early lead on developing driverless cars, it can avoid being squeezed out of the market by tech firms.

Meanwhile, Google has criticised the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) in California for insisting that driverless cars must have a fully licensed driver behind the wheel.

Earlier this week, the DMV published draft regulations stating that truly driverless cars will be "initially excluded" from operation until their safety can be assessed.

Google's director of self-driving cars, Chris Urmson, said the move was "perplexing" and warned that it could prevent the technology from reaching its full potential.

"We've seen in our own testing that drivers can't be trusted to dip in and out of the task of driving when the car is encouraging them to sit back and relax," said Mr Urmson in a blog post.

"Instead of putting a ceiling on the potential of self-driving cars, let's have the courage to imagine what California would be like if we could live without the shackles of stressful commutes, wasted hours, and restricted mobility."

Driverless cars have been pegged as one of the big technology trends of 2016, and are expected to steal the show at the forthcoming Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas.

In fact, Britain could be one of the first countries in the world to get driverless cars, after it emerged that the government has been in talks with Google about testing its autonomous vehicles on UK roads.

The US internet giant has held five face-to-face meetings with the Department for Transport (DfT) in the past two years, according to documents obtained by the Telegraph under the Freedom of Information Act.

They suggest that Google sees the UK as a key market for its driverless cars, due to the country's forward-thinking approach to regulation, and its interest in how the vehicles should be insured.

Other traditional car manufacturers are also developing their own autonomous vehicles, including Mercedes, Audi, BMW and Volvo, and other big tech giants like Apple are also reportedly hoping to get it on the action.

urn:contentItem:5HMS-VGJ1-JCJY-G31B-00000-00Ford starts testing DRIVERLESS cars in California as Google slams 'perplexing' new rules;Ford is taking on Google with its own driverless car, but is California ready for the robotic vehicles to invade its roads?2015-12-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWS,TECHNOLOGY & SCIENCE,TECHNOLOGYFord starts testing DRIVERLESS cars in California as Google slams 'perplexing' new rulesFord is taking on Google with its own driverless car, but is California ready for the robotic vehicles to invade its roads?By Sophie Curtis

It's not just whiz-bang technology companies like Google that are experimenting with driverless vehicles - traditional car companies are also jumping on the bandwagon.

Ford has announced that it will begin testing fully autonomous vehicles on Californian roads in the new year.

The company's Fusion Hybrid sedans have sensors that can detect and track objects in the vehicle's view to provide a 360-degree view of the car's surroundings - including street signs and other vehicles.

Meanwhile, camera sensors serve as the eyes of a vehicle, allowing the car to "see" and sense pedestrians.

Ford now has one of the largest automotive research centres in Silicon Valley, with more than 100 researchers, engineers and scientists on staff at its research and innovation centre in Palo Alto.

It is hoping that by getting an early lead on developing driverless cars, it can avoid being squeezed out of the market by tech firms.

Meanwhile, Google has criticised the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) in California for insisting that driverless cars must have a fully licensed driver behind the wheel.

Earlier this week, the DMV published draft regulations stating that truly driverless cars will be "initially excluded" from operation until their safety can be assessed.

Google's director of self-driving cars, Chris Urmson, said the move was "perplexing" and warned that it could prevent the technology from reaching its full potential.

"We've seen in our own testing that drivers can't be trusted to dip in and out of the task of driving when the car is encouraging them to sit back and relax," said Mr Urmson in a blog post.

"Instead of putting a ceiling on the potential of self-driving cars, let's have the courage to imagine what California would be like if we could live without the shackles of stressful commutes, wasted hours, and restricted mobility."

Driverless cars have been pegged as one of the big technology trends of 2016, and are expected to steal the show at the forthcoming Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas.

In fact, Britain could be one of the first countries in the world to get driverless cars, after it emerged that the government has been in talks with Google about testing its autonomous vehicles on UK roads.

The US internet giant has held five face-to-face meetings with the Department for Transport (DfT) in the past two years, according to documents obtained by the Telegraph under the Freedom of Information Act.

They suggest that Google sees the UK as a key market for its driverless cars, due to the country's forward-thinking approach to regulation, and its interest in how the vehicles should be insured.

Other traditional car manufacturers are also developing their own autonomous vehicles, including Mercedes, Audi, BMW and Volvo, and other big tech giants like Apple are also reportedly hoping to get it on the action.

urn:contentItem:5HRW-YBW1-JCJY-G0WD-00000-00Ford starts testing DRIVERLESS cars in California as Google slams 'perplexing' new rules;Ford is taking on Google with its own driverless car, but is California ready for the robotic vehicles to invade its roads?2016-01-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:31ZLexisNexisNEWS,TECHNOLOGY & SCIENCE,TECHNOLOGYFord starts testing DRIVERLESS cars in California as Google slams 'perplexing' new rulesFord is taking on Google with its own driverless car, but is California ready for the robotic vehicles to invade its roads?By Sophie Curtis

It's not just whiz-bang technology companies like Google that are experimenting with driverless vehicles - traditional car companies are also jumping on the bandwagon.

Ford has announced that it will begin testing fully autonomous vehicles on Californian roads in the new year.

The company's Fusion Hybrid sedans have sensors that can detect and track objects in the vehicle's view to provide a 360-degree view of the car's surroundings - including street signs and other vehicles.

Ford video

Meanwhile, camera sensors serve as the eyes of a vehicle, allowing the car to "see" and sense pedestrians.

Ford now has one of the largest automotive research centres in Silicon Valley, with more than 100 researchers, engineers and scientists on staff at its research and innovation centre in Palo Alto.

It is hoping that by getting an early lead on developing driverless cars, it can avoid being squeezed out of the market by tech firms.

Meanwhile, Google has criticised the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) in California for insisting that driverless cars must have a fully licensed driver behind the wheel.

Earlier this week, the DMV published draft regulations stating that truly driverless cars will be "initially excluded" from operation until their safety can be assessed.

Google's director of self-driving cars, Chris Urmson, said the move was "perplexing" and warned that it could prevent the technology from reaching its full potential.

"We've seen in our own testing that drivers can't be trusted to dip in and out of the task of driving when the car is encouraging them to sit back and relax," said Mr Urmson in a blog post .

"Instead of putting a ceiling on the potential of self-driving cars, let's have the courage to imagine what California would be like if we could live without the shackles of stressful commutes, wasted hours, and restricted mobility."

Driverless cars have been pegged as one of the big technology trends of 2016, and are expected to steal the show at the forthcoming Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas.

In fact, Britain could be one of the first countries in the world to get driverless cars, after it emerged that the government has been in talks with Google about testing its autonomous vehicles on UK roads.

The US internet giant has held five face-to-face meetings with the Department for Transport (DfT) in the past two years, according to documents obtained by the Telegraph under the Freedom of Information Act.

They suggest that Google sees the UK as a key market for its driverless cars, due to the country's forward-thinking approach to regulation, and its interest in how the vehicles should be insured.

Other traditional car manufacturers are also developing their own autonomous vehicles, including Mercedes , Audi , BMW and Volvo, and other big tech giants like Apple are also reportedly hoping to get it on the action.

urn:contentItem:5TSN-PR71-JB20-G1W4-00000-00Forecasted Rain could Trigger Flash Floods and Mudslides; Bare- Knuckle Brawl for Mississippi Senate Seat; Dow Plunges as Tech Shares Tumble; Federal Air Marshals Accused of Hundreds of Firearms Mishaps. Aired 10:30-11a ET2018-11-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:31ZLexisNexisCNN NEWSROOM10:30 AM ESTAdam GanucheauNEWSDomestic112004CN.V11Forecasted Rain could Trigger Flash Floods and Mudslides; Bare- Knuckle Brawl for Mississippi Senate Seat; Dow Plunges as Tech Shares Tumble; Federal Air Marshals Accused of Hundreds of Firearms Mishaps. Aired 10:30-11a ETPoppy Harlow, Jim Sciutto, Paul Vercammen, Julia Chatterley, Drew Griffin

Rain in the forecast tomorrow for Northern California. Mississippi Senate race tightens after racially-charged comments. Dow off 420 points. Federal air marshals accused of more than 200 gun mishaps.

[10:30:21]

JIM SCIUTTO, CNN ANCHOR: Rain is in the forecast tomorrow for Northern California. And that might sound like a good thing, but it could bring both help and problems for firefighters battling the ongoing camp fire.

POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR: The rain could trigger flash floods and mudslides. It would also affect the crews searching for the remains of the victims. We know this morning at least 79 people have died. Almost - 700, rather, remain unaccounted for in this wildfire.

Paul Vercammen joins us from Paradise, California. Paul, you know, what are they up against as they continue to fight this right now?

PAUL VERCAMMEN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Well, let's just show you, Poppy and Jim, what they're up against is an immense debris field, never seen before in California because you never had it where a small city was obliterated. Look at the restaurant that was behind me. You can see the chairs where people sat.

And one of the worries for first responders, do you see all of that debris and ash? It can be moved along by water rather quickly. And what they fear is lots of the stuff is going to go down the hill, as they call it here in Butte County, and what could complicate things for first responders is if that becomes an ashy slurry mess, and they're on these mountain roads trying to take care of their business, they will be in treacherous conditions. They're also worried about people sleeping outside. They have done a very good job from what we have seen so far in moving people out of makeshift camps and into the shelters, but that's what they're worried about, this becoming one muddy problem in the middle of what is continuing to be a cleanup of a fire.

SCIUTTO: Last thing those poor people there need. And thanks for continuing to follow that story. We're going to keep at it because the suffering continues there.

HARLOW: It does continue.

OK. Let's take a quick look at the markets right now. About an hour into trading and the Dow is off 472 points, largely a sell-off driven by concerns about technology companies. We'll get a live update from the New York Stock Exchange next.

[10:36:55] HARLOW: All right. Welcome back.

In just hours, a highly anticipated debate takes place for the Mississippi Senate seat, a seat that once looked like a slam dunk for Republicans. That until the Republican candidate, Cindy Hyde Smith, was caught on tape joking about going to a public hanging. In another recording, she said she would welcome certain forms of voter suppression. Here team later said she was joking about that as well. But it has really opened the door for the Democratic candidate Mike Espy, a former Congressman, who if he wins will be the first black senator from Mississippi in over a century. The two face off in a run- off one week from today.

Adam Ganucheau is with us, political reporter from "Mississippi Today." Good morning. Thank you for being here.

I'm fascinated by this for so many reasons, including the fact that this is a state that the president won by nearly 18 percent. This should be in the bag for Republicans. It is not, largely because of these controversial comments. Could we see an Alabama-style upset on Tuesday in your state?

ADAM GANUCHEAU, POLITICAL REPORTER, "MISSISSIPPI TODAY": Well, I think Democrats and Republicans both are now thinking it's possible, Poppy. You know, it's a tough thing for a Democrat in Mississippi to win. I guess that's the bottom line. But reports this week have Espy down just five points. And as you said, in Mississippi, that's a really big deal. These two videos that have surfaced in the last week or two, you know, really, I think, have tightened this race and made sort of this national intrigue and brought a lot of out of state cash to Mississippi.

HARLOW: You know, what I think is interesting is sort of the defense that the Republican candidate, that she and her team are taking here because - I mean, she's essentially taking a page Hyde Smith is out of the Trump playbook. Because Espy called her a walking stereotype who is an embarrassment to the state, those are his words. She responds on Twitter saying, is it still OK to have a sense of humor in America? Isn't it? I mean, are the people of Mississippi laughing?

GANUCHEAU: Well, you know, it just depends on who you talk to. I will say this. There's not a single Mississippian that either myself or my colleagues have spoken with in the last two weeks who haven't at least heard this video or seen this video.

HARLOW: Interesting.

GANUCHEAU: You know, it is sort of, you know, split by racial lines and of course by party lines to some degree, but without exception, the Mississippians I think who are sort of defending this or you know calling this sort of the attack of the politically correct in America or the state of Mississippi, without exception, those are conservative white people. And most of the people who are upset about this are of course African-Americans in Mississippi.

HARLOW: Which make up about 38 percent of the electorate in Mississippi, African-Americans and let's not forget, Mississippi had more lynchings that are on record, of course, many lynchings were not ever recorded, but more than 600 lynchings on record, making it the highest number in any state in this country. But the way that the Democrat Mike Espy is running is also really interesting to me because he's got some big, you know, Democrat names coming there for him. Democratic Senator Kamala Harris of California, and he's embracing that, but he's also making very clear he's not a liberal, liberal.

[10:40:04] GANUCHEAU: That's right. You have to remember that, you know, Mike Espy has already made history in Mississippi. He was the first African-American Congressman in the state since reconstruction. If he were elected, he would be, like you said, the first African- American senator elected by popular vote in Mississippi, at least, back to reconstruction. But you know he really has embraced Senator Kamala Harris this week, Senator Cory Booker.

You know I was in a classroom this week with some African-American students. Elementary school students, and when Espy was there, he sort of talked about, you know, there have only been 10 U.S. Senators in history of the country that are African-American. So you know he's really pushing this. And you know, I think at this point, that's certainly a strategy of theirs, of sort of to you know, talk about that history, how he's already made history and sort of pitch how he could continue that.

HARLOW: So the president will be there on Monday, trying to make the final push that clearly Hyde Smith's team thinks they need to get over the finish line here for the election on Tuesday. But before you go, there is controversy also that is surrounding Espy. It has to do with lobbying work that he did back in 2010. This was for the Ivory Coast. Of course, the president at the time is now being tried in the ICC for crimes against humanity. There's a controversy over payments that he received. Is that weighing on him?

GANUCHEAU: I mean, I think it's something he certainly had to deal with. He's faced several, you know sort of questions about that. Espy and Hyde Smith actually tonight are having their first and what looks like their only debate before next week's election. I think you know we can expect that to come up. You know, for Espy's part, he's sort of said, you know, backed out of this. He said that in 2011, and then in 2014, there was a Department of Justice filing that suggested he actually got full payment.

HARLOW: Right.

GANUCHEAU: So, it's something that he's going to have to continue to answer to. It's certainly affected his campaign.

HARLOW: Sure. You'll have a late night covering that debate. It will be an interesting and important one. Adam, we appreciate you joining us. Thank you so much.

We're going to be right back with a quick check on the markets. The Dow off 420 points at the moment.

[10:46:45] HARLOW: All right. This morning we're keeping a very close eye on Wall Street. There's why. You've got the Dow off 414 points, largely driven by a sell-off in tech stocks.

SCIUTTO: Joining us now from the New York Stock Exchange, CNN business anchor and anchor of "First Move" Julia Chatterley. So, Julia, we have seen a fair number of days like this. Several hundred points down, 1 percent, 2 percent. Of course, the market over the course of the year, flat, it's actually below flat at this point. But when you're speaking to traders there, what do they see different in the last several days and with today's fall? Are they concerned this is part of something bigger?

JULIA CHATTERLEY, CNN ANCHOR, "FIRST MOVE": That's a great question, Jim, a great view on the show. OK, I give you two things. One, today for the first time all year, we have completely wiped out the gains that the U.S. equity markets have made. So just in terms of sentiment, people are looking at the situation now and going, does this mean it's a good opportunity to get back into the market and buy? Or do you stand back and see how much further this can fall?

The other thing is, the thing that's been lifting the markets all year has been the big tech stocks, Apple, Amazon, two great examples. And suddenly we're seeing those stocks down 20 percent from the highs. So people are looking at this and going, if they're not going to lead the border markets higher, what is? Those two things I think are very important here. And it's not just about stocks. Oil prices today, they're off 6 percent. There's just a real sense of uncertainty in these markets. And I tie it back to trade and the headlines that we got over the weekend coming into this week. And of course, Poppy, I know you'll know this very well. The Federal Reserve, will Jay Powell continue to hike rates, and the fear remains that he'll overshoot in terms of interest rates. And that weighs growth here too.

HARLOW: All great points. When you look at the sell-off in tech stocks, though, it's the driver today, as you noted. And it doesn't seem like it's going to be a one-off, Julia, or a just for now. I mean what these tech companies are looking at is what's facing Facebook right now after that damning "New York Times" report, and the regulation in Europe with GDRP, and the reality that a reckoning is coming, right? A reckoning is coming for these companies that will fundamentally change the way they have to do business. And that's going to be a prolonged bit of pain for them, no?

CHATTERLEY: I couldn't agree more. I mean we've had Tim Cook this week saying, guys, get ready. More regulation is coming. You're going to have to get used to it. Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg has been under the spotlight for the last few months. We have seen that stock punished. Even the ones that we thought were the strongest like Apple. They're having reports now that they're struggling to sell iPhones to the size that they were hoping to. So all around, there's individual stories that mean they're going to be challenged going forward. And it's a real headache. You know and I take it back to trade. A lot of people I'm speaking to right now are saying when you look at the tensions between Vice President Mike Pence at the weekend with Xi Jinping, there's not going to be a solution here either anytime soon. It's tough.

HARLOW: Yes.

SCIUTTO: Julia Chatterley, we know we're going to keep coming back to you there as we follow this. Thanks very much.

Coming up next, a stunning new CNN investigation uncovers hundreds of mishaps involving armed Federal Air Marshals and their firearms.

[10:54:25] SCIUTTO: Loaded guns left behind in bathrooms. Accidental misfires onboard. Officers hired to keep you safe on airplanes are now accused in a range of gun misuse cases.

HARLOW: This is all according to the CNN investigation that our colleague Drew Griffin did that uncovered more than 200 alleged gun mishaps by Federal Air Marshals. Our senior investigative correspondent Drew Griffin is here. This is stunning, Drew.

DREW GRIFFIN, CNN SENIOR INVESTIGATIVE CORRESPONDENT: You know, guys, just last month, yet another air marshal committed suicide. We've reported extensively on these suicides by the air marshals in the past. It's what prompted us to ask the federal government for every record involving mishaps and air marshals. This is what we found.

[10:55:05] (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GRIFFIN (voice-over): These documents released to CNN through a Freedom of Information Act request reveal more than 200 cases of alleged misconduct by Federal Air Marshals involving firearms. Men and women supposedly well trained to use their weapons in one of the most dangerous environments. Misplacing, misfiring. Even accidentally and not so accidentally shooting themselves. Documents released to CNN include 19 accidental discharges, including an air marshal who caused a gunshot wound to his right foot. Another accidentally discharged his firearm in a hotel room, hitting a television in the adjoining room. More than 70 cases of air marshals losing weapons, three times air marshals have left their service weapons in an airplane's bathroom. They've left weapons in restrooms, bars, even a bed, bath, and beyond in New Jersey. In at least 13 cases, alcohol was involved.

After releasing the documents, the Federal Air Marshal Service invited CNN to the Air Marshal Training Academy outside of Atlantic City, New Jersey, where new air marshals are taught how to handle their weapons and top instructor Daniel Kowal admitted the reports are embarrassing.

DANIEL KOWAL, SUPERVISORY AIR MARSHAL: We look at what was the underlying cause, what happened? If and when training failed, how and why did it fail? How do we plug that gap? How do we fix that? Our goal as the training department is to strive for zero percent error.

GRIFFIN: It's hard to compare if air marshals are more or less dangerous with weapons than other law enforcement agencies because the number of air marshals is classified. But former air marshals tell CNN any mishap is unacceptable because their agents operate at 34,000 feet.

HENRY PRESTON, FORMER AIR MARSHAL TRAINING INSTRUCTOR: There's no backup. You have got to take care of business. And you got to do it very quickly and efficiently.

GRIFFIN: Henry Preston, who spent 10 years in the service, says he observed a decline in weapons training and practice, year by year. Inconsistencies he said, that could contribute to mistakes.

PRESTON: They need additional training. There's no doubt about it.

GRIFFIN: Oddly, three of the apparent mishaps occurred during firearms training. In one case, an instructor allegedly threw training bullets called Simunition into an open flame. They exploded, and one staff member was struck in the face by flying debris. Problems are nothing new to the controversial air marshal service. CNN has previously reported agents have continually complained about low morale, low staffing, grueling hours.

A 2012 sleep study obtained by CNN shows 75 percent of domestic air marshals were flying while sleep deficient. That study found that lack of sleep puts them at greater incidents of serious errors. Critics question if air marshals are even necessary. Last year, the Department of Homeland Security's inspector general slammed the air marshal service and said its contribution to aviation transportation security is questionable. Ohio state professor John Mueller, who studies the efficiencies of security measures, says nearly $1 billion agency is almost worthless.

JOHN MUELLER, POLITICAL SCIENTIST, OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY: Federal Air Marshals simply don't pass muster in terms of cost/benefit analysis. They deliver about 5 cents or maybe 10 cents of benefit for every dollar that's spent on them.

GRIFFIN: Now, the revelation that at least 200 cases where agents made dangerous mistakes is yet another strike against the Federal Air Marshals program.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

GRIFFIN: The TSA tells us the air marshals are trained to the highest levels. The problem, Poppy and Jim, is the air marshals we have been talking to say that's just not true. And in 2016, the government accountability office said the record keeping is so bad that it's really hard to tell if these agents are trained and retrained to proper specifications. TSA insists that's all fixed now.

SCIUTTO: The air marshals themselves are identifying this is a problem. I'm curious, just to be clear. Did any of these mishaps happen in the air with passengers onboard? Were passengers put in danger?

GRIFFIN: Several cases where these guns that were left in airplane bathrooms were found by the passengers themselves. That's how these guns were discovered. So the answer is yes. Does that put a passenger in danger? Well, I guess it depends on which passenger picks it up. But I would say absolutely.

HARLOW: I'm struck by so much in your report, but especially the record keeping. The record keeping was so messy that they don't really have the ability to say were these people trained up to snuff or not. How can that be?

GRIFFIN: Poppy, I have been reporting on the air marshal service for 10 years. This is a service that got ramped up right after 9/11. I believe ill thought out and it's been a mess ever since. And since we've hardened the cockpit doors, many people just say we don't need these guys sitting on planes.

HARLOW: Wow.

SCIUTTO: Interesting question. Thanks very much for joining us today. I'm Jim Sciutto.

HARLOW: I'm Poppy Harlow. We'll see you back here tomorrow morning. "At This Hour" with Kate Bolduan starts now.
