urn:contentItem:5X1N-HBC1-DYTN-N3DW-00000-00Forecasts for Executives and Investors2019-08-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:31ZLexisNexisForecasts for Executives and InvestorsThe Kiplinger Washington EditorsWashington Aug. 30, 2019

Dear Client:

In an effort to rein in internet giants...

Lawmakers are homing in on a new tactic:

Make sites more responsible for user posts.

How? Reduce or scrap their legal immunity for the flood of content that is uploaded by their users.

TECH

Websites received liability protection in 1996. Congress wanted to encourage platforms to moderate content and remove objectionable posts... violent material, hate speech, etc...without the prospect of being slammed with lawsuits over users' material.

The move was pivotal in creating today's web by ushering in an era of popular, user-driven sites... Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, Wikipedia, Yelp, etc.

But after a series of Big Tech missteps...

Lawmakers from both parties want a redo of Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, the brief section that some say "created the internet."

Republicans are leading the charge, saying Facebook and others have too much power over speech and discriminate against conservatives. Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO) wants legal immunity that is premised on neutrality: Popular web platforms would have to prove to regulators that their policies for deleting posts and curating content were politically neutral.

Meanwhile, the Trump administration is reportedly mulling taking action: The Federal Trade Comm. and Federal Communications Comm. would vet the policies of websites. An executive order of that kind would be hit with lawsuits and likely fail.

Democrats, too, question legal protections unless web giants do a lot more to fight misinformation, terrorist content, foreign election meddling, harassment, etc.

The legal protections that online platforms enjoy today won't be fully eliminated.

But changes around the edges are coming. Among the most likely ideas: Make sites shed more light on how they personalize content, delete certain material or ban users. Hold web platforms more accountable for some moneymaking content, such as YouTube's business partnerships with outside video makers. Require websites to be more accountable for the ads they run or for posts that users pay to promote.

Lawmakers recently narrowed protections of Section 230 for posted material relating to sex trafficking, the first major change since 1996. Other notable exceptions already in the law include intellectual property and federal criminal prosecutions. Otherwise, sites aren't on the hook for hosted content, as traditional publishers are.

The talk in Washington will jolt Big Tech into taking major voluntary action in a rush to avoid a disruption of its business models. Expect more transparency in how behind-the-scenes decisions happen...why one sees a recommended video, for instance, or how to appeal if a post is removed. Users will get more control, too.

Lawmakers will lean on rhetoric for now, as legislation seems a way off.

TRADE

Just how bad are U.S.-China trade relations now as the tariffs pile up?

The two sides have even disagreed about whether they're on speaking terms. In the wake of the latest hike in duties on each other's imports, President Trump said that Chinese officials called to restart talks, only for Beijing to say otherwise.

Dialogue will start up again at some point. Just don't expect any breakthrough ending the trade war between the world's top two economies. The issues they differ on, such as protecting American intellectual property and giving U.S. firms more access to the Chinese market, are too thorny for a deal to happen before next Nov.'s elections.

Europe's export-oriented economies will continue to suffer. The hit to China caused by U.S. tariffs means shrinking demand for capital equipment and other goods that Germany, in particular, ships to China. Europe's economic woes are far from over.

Sizable U.S. oil exports to China have dodged a tariff bullet. For now. Beijing was planning to apply duties to imports of U.S. crude, effective Sept. 1. But China is holding off on those and other duties for now in a bid to defuse tensions. Not long ago, China was the third-largest buyer of America's expanding oil bounty, behind South Korea and Canada, though its imports of U.S. crude are off 63% this year.

U.S. natural gas is already a casualty of the trade war. China ranks second among importers of liquefied natural gas, but its intake of U.S. LNG is down 76%.

THE ECONOMY

Expect factory activity to keep weakening as manufacturers curb production because of the uncertainties created by the trade situation. Inventory growth is slowing, a sign that manufacturers expect demand for their products to decline. Some wholesalers and retailers will keep stocking up for now in order to beat hikes in tariffs on Chinese imports, but that process figures to run its course fairly soon. And declining inventories subtract from GDP, to the tune of a tenth of a point in 2019 and a quarter of a point next year, at a time when economic growth is already slowing.

CREDIT

Interest rates show little sign of reversing their recent slide. How low they'll go is hard to say, but it's likely that the yield on the 10-year Treasury note won't return to 2% anytime soon. It now trades near 1.5%, versus 2018's peak of 3.25%. Even at this low level, foreign investors who face negative rates at home are buying.

Watch for the average rate on 30-year mortgages to dip below 3.5%. The rate for a 15-year loan: Below 3%. Yields on corporate and municipal debt will fall more, too, a sign that investors are seeking safety but aren't alarmed about the economy just yet.

But note that rates on credit cards are the highest in more than 20 years: 17.14% on average as of May. That's partly a product of the Federal Reserve's hikes on its short-term rate, which card lenders use as a benchmark for their own rates.

The cost of plastic won't decline much, even as the Fed reverses course. Some major lenders have dialed back their card rates a bit this summer, but in general, they won't be quick to pass interest savings on to their customers. (Imagine that.)

INVESTING

When considering international stocks, don't overlook Australian shares, say the editors of Kiplinger's Personal Finance magazine. Economic growth down under is robust. Many Australian stocks sport low prices and high dividends.

Among funds, consider the iShares MSCI Australia exchange-traded fund, a good way to gain broad exposure to the Aussie economy. It's weighted toward banks and other financial firms, and yields much more than the S&P 500 index's 2% payout.

Also check out Aberdeen Australia Equity, a closed-end fund that trades at a discount to the market value of its holdings, making it potentially undervalued.

And First Trust Australia Alphadex, a specialty ETF that invests in stocks that look promising but that aren't easy for American investors to buy directly.

Individual Australian stocks worth a look: Westpac Banking. BHP Group, the mining giant. Retailer Woolworths Group (available through specialty brokers).

THE WORLD

U.S. foreign policy is suffering setbacks all over the Korean Peninsula.

The White House is struggling to reboot nuclear talks with North Korea, dealing instead with continued complaints and missile launches from Pyongyang. The North Koreans also canceled peace talks with their South Korean counterparts.

South Korea is in an escalating feud with Japan, another American ally. What began as a trade dispute has become a national security issue after Seoul formally withdrew from a military-intelligence-sharing agreement with Tokyo.

What will the Trump administration do? On North Korea, nothing...

For now. The president has mostly ignored Pyongyang's demands for sanctions relief and its missile tests, so long as they don't threaten the U.S.

Expect Pyongyang to up the ante to get President Trump's attention. Tensions will rise if North Korea crosses Trump's redline: Testing a missile capable of reaching the U.S. Don't be surprised if Kim Jong Un takes advantage of the U.S.-China trade war by convincing Beijing to go easy on sanctions.

On South Korea, the U.S. is attempting to conduct damage control.

But the situation will worsen before it improves. The list of issues dividing Seoul and Tokyo is long. Some of them go back decades, even centuries.

MIDDLE EAST

Tensions between the U.S. and Iran appear to finally be easing after months of escalation following America's withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal. Mediation by French President Emmanuel Macron has both sides in a better mood.

But don't expect much diplomatic progress anytime soon, despite signs that both sides are increasingly willing to talk. In fact, tensions may escalate again in the coming months as Tehran tries to strengthen its hand in potential negotiations.

POLITICS

President Trump continues to attract primary challengers. The latest: Joe Walsh, a former Republican congressman turned talk radio host who once ranked among Trump's greatest supporters. Walsh joins Bill Weld, the former Mass. governor. Mark Sanford, the one-time governor and congressman from S.C., also says he's considering entering the GOP presidential primary.

Can they beat Trump? Unlikely. The president has a sky-high approval rating among Republicans. Early polls show him beating Weld by 70-plus percentage points.

IN THE STATES

While most state and local governments are in decent financial shape...

Many are busy preparing for a potential recession, socking away money and keeping a lid on recurring expenditures for fear of being caught off guard.

States will continue adding to their rainy-day funds. 37 did so this year, buoyed by strong tax collections. (Tax revenues beat or met expectations in 38 states in FY 2019.) As a percentage of state spending, rainy-day funds are at record levels.

And setting aside cash for infrastructure projects...one-time expenditures that will not be a continual drain on future budgets. Plus, if a recession strikes, governments can take back the money and fund the projects with bonds instead.

A new Calif. law barring hairstyle discrimination is part of a new trend. Taking effect next year, the law protects both hairstyles and hair textures associated with a person's race, including braids, Afros and dreadlocks. It will apply to employers with five or more employees. Calif. often takes the lead with new workplace laws.

Other states are looking at the idea. N.Y. already passed a similar law, and legislation is pending in Mich. and N.J. More are expected to follow suit.

Employers may want to review and update grooming/appearance policies to address hair textures and styles. Also, train hiring managers to ensure that job applicants aren't rated unfavorably because of a race-associated hairstyle.

AG

Democrats are angling for a larger share of the farm vote in 2020... a key constituency for President Trump. Farmers voted overwhelmingly for Trump in 2016, hoping his policies would boost the flagging rural economy.

Trade and ethanol have given the party an opening. Few farmers are happy with how Trump's trade war is playing out, despite supporting his broader goal of reducing barriers to U.S. exports. They also don't like his approach to ethanol, which critics say is undermined by the many waivers given to small oil refiners.

Both issues exacerbate other economic woes in farm country...low prices for key commodities, declining farm income, rising debt and delinquency, etc.

Most polls show Trump remains popular among farmers, though his support has eroded somewhat, depending on the survey. The latest Farm Journal Pulse poll, for example, shows 71% of farmers approving of Trump, down from 79% in July.

But even small-scale defections could help tip the balance in some key states that are critical to Trump's reelection chances next year, as they were in 2016. Think Iowa, Mich., Ohio, Pa. and Wis. Trump is polling poorly in all five states.

HEMP

Hemp still faces some hazy legal questions, despite Congress taking action last year to legalize the plant nationwide. Last winter, a long-haul trucker was charged with weed trafficking while carrying 6,700 pounds of industrial hemp through Idaho. Cannabis is illegal in the state, and hemp is considered marijuana under Idaho law. Hemp contains trace elements of THC, the psychoactive chemical found in weed, though you can't get high smoking or ingesting the plant. The outcome of the case will be a significant test of how and where hemp can be shipped in the U.S.

The Dept. of Agriculture has attempted to clear up the legal mess. In May, USDA issued a legal opinion that states cannot prohibit the interstate transportation of lawfully produced hemp. A legally binding final hemp reg is expected later this year. A handful of states bar the cultivation of hemp, a potential roadblock to the industry.

ALCOHOL SALES

It's getting easier to grab a beer at college football games. A growing tally of colleges and athletic conferences are allowing alcohol sales at stadiums. The powerhouse Southeastern Conference lifted its ban on alcohol, for example. The North Carolina legislature this year OK'd alcohol at state university athletic events.

Some schools are hoping beer can raise attendance, which has been down at college football games in recent years. It can also boost revenue. Another factor: Selling alcohol can curb binge drinking, since it cuts back on pregame excess.

WORLD CAPITALS

Surprised that Indonesia is planning to move its capital city? Don't be.

Many countries have outgrown their capitals. The long list includes Brazil and Nigeria, which built Brasília and Abuja when their capitals became too crowded.

Even the U.S. flirted with the idea earlier in its history. Washington, D.C., became the capital in 1800, replacing Philadelphia. After the Civil War, Congress considered moving the capital to the West, citing D.C.'s substandard infrastructure and overcrowded conditions, among other things. The city improved; the idea died.

Indonesia will build a new capital on Borneo to supplant overcrowded Jakarta, which also is slowly sinking into the sea. The move will cost the country $33 billion.

urn:contentItem:5WT0-RNP1-JCBK-Y39D-00000-00Forecasts for Executives and Investors2019-08-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:31ZLexisNexisForecasts for Executives and InvestorsThe Kiplinger Washington EditorsWashington Aug. 23, 2019

Dear Client:

The warning signs are getting stronger. And financial markets are growing nervous. Risks to the economic expansion are rising. But we still don't think a recession is near.

U.S. ECONOMY

It's natural to worry about the economy.

Bond yields are down...a sign that investors are concerned about the prospects for GDP growth. Yields on long-term bonds have slipped below those on short-term debt...often a sign of recession ahead.

Commodity prices are softening...again, a signal that future economic activity will be weak.

Manufacturing is contracting in the U.S. and across the world as the trade war continues.

Still, there are reasons for some optimism.

Most of them hinge on the U.S. consumer. Despite talk of trade wars and manufacturing slumps and possible recession in Europe...all real problems... U.S. consumers continue to shop and spend freely. Unemployment is near a 50-year low. Wages are up. Home values and 401(k) balances are quite high.

Shoppers will have to carry the load for now because weak business investment shows no sign of perking up anytime soon.

Odds are they'll be able to. Some readings on consumer sentiment have declined lately, and a few categories of spending are starting to tail off. But for the most part, folks are spending, even on discretionary things like boats.

None of this means that all is well with the economy. Growth is slowing after coming in strong last year. There are plenty of problems overseas: Brexit. Weakness across Europe. A sharp slowdown in China. Flagging global trade.

The best-case scenario: GDP gains of 2.3% this year and 1.8% next year... far short of recession, but no boom, either. For some industries, such as farming and manufacturing, business conditions will continue to feel akin to a recession.

Growth could also slow more sharply, to 1% or even less next year...

If consumers get spooked by worrisome economic headlines. Manufacturing makes up only 11% of the overall economy, but if job losses there start to mount and cause the unemployment rate to inch up, other workers could get nervous. That in turn would ding consumer spending, which accounts for 68% of GDP.

Whether the economy slows modestly or sharply, a few things seem clear:

Interest rates will stay quite low, especially after the Federal Reserve implements additional rate cuts to stave off potential damage from the trade war.

Prices of industrial metals and other commodities will remain muted, too.

The global economy will stay shaky. And the trade situation will worsen before it gets better...both the U.S. and China are clearly digging in for a long fight.

MORE ECONOMY

Note the differing economic trajectories of regions around the country.

The Northeast and Midwest are under the greatest strain as trade tensions with China and other countries sow uncertainty and spark stock market fluctuations. The pressure is felt by financial services firms in the Northeast, with corporate profits under pressure, along with agriculture and oil firms in the Midwest. The loss of China as a market for soybeans and other crops, plus adverse weather, are slamming farmers.

Meanwhile, high-tech firms put the West and other areas on sounder footing. Calif.'s Silicon Valley and Wash.'s Puget Sound still attract ample venture capital. Fla. is gaining tech dollars, too. Other spots are benefiting from big tech's expansion: Amazon's move to Northern Virginia and Google's growth in Texas, for instance.

TRADE

Tensions will climb with Europe and Japan over the specter of auto tariffs as President Trump keeps the tariff threat alive. The administration agreed in May to a six-month delay on slapping 25% tariffs on imported cars and parts from the European Union and Japan. But Trump says tariffs are "never off the table."

U.S. auto tariffs would have a big effect on global trade. Autos and parts make up 8% of global trade volume. A 25% duty would hike new-car prices by $2,750, on average, and lead to spikes in used-car prices. Germany would take the biggest hit in the EU, as it makes up 55% of EU auto exports and is on the verge of a recession.

Autos are just a piece of a larger discussion about a trade deal with the EU. Trump's tactics are also aimed at reducing EU duties on industrial and farm imports.

It's unlikely that the trade war will morph into a damaging currency war.

But the danger will remain front and center as Trump refuses to rule out the possibility of using measures to counter the greenback's strength. The decision in early Aug. to label Beijing a currency manipulator for the first time since 1994 has heightened market worries about trade battles spilling over into global currencies.

Deliberate devaluations are rare and not easy to achieve. One big reason: Currency markets are so huge, with roughly $5 trillion per day changing hands and about $4 trillion of those trades involving the dollar. Even if the Treasury Dept. took sweeping action to weaken the dollar, it would need help from other nations.

Past currency interventions were coordinated efforts. The most famous: The U.S.-engineered Plaza Accord of 1985 with France, Germany, Britain and Japan.

FINANCE

The Federal Reserve is creating a real-time payments system. Called FedNow, the system will narrow the amount of time between when money is deposited or transferred into an account and when it is available for use. At the present time, banks issue IOUs to each other to make funds immediately available to customers. Many of the transactions, from direct deposits to bill payments, are settled in batches three times per day during business hours. FedNow will launch in four to five years.

The Fed's system will compete with another one owned by the large banks, started in 2017 and run by the Clearing House. Big banks aren't fond of the Fed move, but the Fed says having two competitors will bring down prices and spur innovation.

The U.S. is playing catch-up with other countries, such as Brazil, Turkey, Japan and Singapore, that can handle real-time payments. Consumers nowadays expect instant money transfers as they shop online or send money via mobile app.

REAL ESTATE

Uncle Sam is taking action to spur condo purchases by first-time buyers. The Federal Housing Admin. is tweaking the rules for the types of mortgages that it will insure at condominium developments. After the housing crash, regulations were tightened, and FHA-backed mortgages for condos sank from 72,900 in 2010 to 16,200 in 2018. Today, just 6.5% of the 150,000 condo developments in the U.S. are eligible for FHA-backed mortgages. The new rules, which will increase that tally with looser requirements that cover many more condos, will take effect in Oct.

Expect the move to boost the entry-level condo market in many areas.

POLITICS

An upcoming special election in N.C. is effectively a harbinger of 2020.

Both parties are desperate to win the state's ninth congressional district, which remains up for grabs after election fraud invalidated the 2018 result.

The district backed President Trump in 2016 by more than 11 points and demographically favors the GOP, with its sizable share of white rural voters.

But polls suggest a tight race on Sept. 10, and the Democrat, Dan McCready, has raised three times as much money as his Republican opponent, Dan Bishop.

Conservative groups are pouring money into the race to put Bishop over the top. The state senator has closely tied himself to Trump, so a loss in this conservative-leaning district would prompt panic throughout the party. But a Bishop win might encourage more Republicans to ally with Trump in 2020.

ELECTRONS

States will do more to guard against foreign meddling in U.S. elections in the absence of help from Congress. Federal election-security legislation remains bogged down by partisan bickering and is unlikely to pass anytime soon.

Some examples: Del. unveiled new voting machines this year. S.C. will have a new, paper-based voting system next year. And Ga. is contracting with a Denver-based company for a combined touch screen/paper ballot system.

REGS

A new Trump administration rule puts tighter limits on legal immigration.

The target: Immigrants who use or are likely to use public benefits, such as food stamps and Medicaid. Set to take effect Oct. 15, the rule would make it more difficult for such individuals to obtain a green card or extend a temporary visa.

The goal: Shift the U.S. to a more skills-based immigration system by favoring wealthier, educated immigrants who can support themselves. The change will affect immigration from Latin America the most, Europe and Canada the least.

Businesses already short of workers will feel the effect...farms, hotels, restaurants, home health care providers. All rely on low-income, legal immigrant labor.

Legal challenges will be swift and numerous. Calif. and three other states filed the latest lawsuit, joining other states, counties and nonprofit groups.

Industry groups are lauding a proposal to ease driving rules for truckers... revised every eight to nine years...from the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Admin.

What's new? Drivers could hit pause on their 14-hours-of-service clock to take an off-duty break of at least 30 minutes, but not more than three hours, so long as they take 10 consecutive hours off duty at the end of their shift.

Plus more flexibility for rest breaks and off-duty time. For example, drivers could split their required 10 hours off duty into two periods, one with seven hours, at least, spent in the sleeper berth; the other must be at least two consecutive hours.

Drivers could also extend their workday if affected by adverse conditions, such as bad weather and traffic congestion, by up to two additional hours.

For short-haul truckers: Expanded on-duty time and geographical range. These are truckers who make local deliveries, mostly within an urban area.

LABOR

Proposed changes would make it easier for workers to boot out unions, the first of many expected tweaks to Obama-era union election rules by the National Labor Relations Board, now controlled by a Republican majority.

A decertifying election can be held, despite charges of unfair labor practices. Currently, such charges can delay an election by months, even years. The proposal would allow the vote to proceed, but a ballot count must wait till the charge is resolved.

Employees will have a 45-day window to request a vote to decertify a union once an employer has voluntarily recognized it. Under current union election rules, a dissenting employee can't request a vote for at least six months, sometimes longer.

AG

Be skeptical of the Dept. of Agriculture's latest corn and soybean forecasts. Many analysts say they're at odds with what's happening on the ground... the yield estimates in particular. USDA's predictions of 169.5 bushels per acre for corn and 48.5 for soybeans are optimistic, they say, especially in a year rife with bad weather and late planting. For example, around 40% of this year's corn crop was planted in June. Yields decline significantly on corn planted after May 20.

Private estimates paint a less sunny picture. A recent tour of key farm states by Gro Intelligence found corn yields six bushels per acre and soybean yields four bushels per acre below USDA estimates. Yields in the eastern Corn Belt...Ill., Ind., Ohio...were off as much as 24 bushels per acre for corn, nine bushels for soybeans.

Marijuana legalization has been a tax windfall for participating states.

But even with some form of legality in 34 states, the black market thrives. Because of heavy taxation and regulation, many growers have decided not to go legit. One study valued the illegal trade at $70 billion...seven times the legal market's size.

Why hasn't the black market shut down? Illegal weed generally costs less.

Many cities in Calif., the largest fully legal market, won't allow dispensaries, turning customers to the black market. And the counterculture that developed around marijuana's illegality is so entrenched, many members don't trust the changes.

Look for states to tweak their tax structures to be more price-competitive. They'll also stress quality control. And crack down on those who won't come around.

THE WORLD

The longest war in American history is at least one step closer to ending.

The U.S. is on the verge of a deal to withdraw troops from Afghanistan following months of talks with Taliban leaders. The plan: The U.S. will start removing its roughly 14,000 troops from the country if the Taliban refuse terrorists safe harbor.

One thing is clear: President Trump wants out before the 2020 elections, allowing him to fulfill a key campaign promise. The U.S. would withdraw 5,000 troops as part of the deal with the Taliban, which the White House wants done by Sept. 1

But plenty of questions remain. Will the U.S. push for a broader peace deal between the Taliban and Afghan government? Unclear. The Trump administration has sent mixed messages. Also unclear: Will Trump back down? Fellow Republicans, who fear a worsening terrorist threat from ISIS and others, are pushing back hard.

AIRLINES

Don't expect to see Boeing's 737 Max jet in the air again until at least Jan. The plane has been grounded since mid-March. Even after the software is fixed and OK'd by the Federal Aviation Admin., it will take airlines at least a month to train pilots and reactivate the nearly 400 Max jet planes gathering dust at airports.

The delay throws a wrench into carriers' scheduling for the holiday season. Pulling the jet from schedules will cause flight cancellations and travel disruptions. It could also push up prices and force travelers to book less convenient routes. The grounding is costly for U.S. carriers, which are leasing planes from other airlines to make up capacity. They're also using older, less fuel-efficient planes, upping costs and cutting profits. Things will get worse as delivery dates for new Max jets slip. Southwest and American are feeling it most. Delta doesn't have any Maxes in its fleet.

Dear Client:

Advertising has reached a tipping point.

Digital will soon be the leading medium. It grabs over 40% of spending and is growing rapidly, poised to overtake traditional media...TV, print, etc.

How can businesses spend ad dollars wisely

Here are some key trends and timely tips.

SELLING

Googleand Facebook dominate digital, accounting for 58% of online ad spending. Google's share is 37%. Facebook...21%. Amazon is in a distant third place, with 4% of all ad dollars, but it's making a major push and has room to run.

On social media, flashy visuals rule the day. Video ads are proliferating and are about to be 25% of all digital ad spending. Facebook-owned Instagram, a photo-sharing app, is seeing torrid video ad growth.

Digital upgrades are helping TV and radio, making it easier to tally audiences and improve ads. Traditional TV viewers will dip slightly in years ahead, but TV delivered over the web is growing swiftly. Radio has received a boost from web-connected speakers.

Print will continue its decline in ad spending. Trade publications will tend to hold steady, though.

Billboards, digital displays and other out-of-home advertising are growing in terms of dollars spent. Tech giants such as Apple and Netflix have spent heavily.

Other areas gaining traction: Video games, movie theaters and podcasts.

Some advice for sellers trying to navigate the fast-changing ad landscape:

Go where your customers are. For niche audiences: Social media, search or display ads on Google and Amazon, infomercials on your website or event hosting are good choices. Targeting other businesses? Skip other social apps and try LinkedIn.

Focus on improving mobile sites as more web surfers rely on smartphones. Sites have to load fast and the buying process has to be simple, as finicky customers will ditch a slow mobile site in a heartbeat. Keep video ads short and text minimal.

Save money with do-it-yourself advertising by cutting out the middleman. Both Google and Amazonare focused on making it easier to place your own online ads.

Try Amazon if you haven't before. Its conversion rate...the portion of people who click or buy...is far higher than Google's. Folks on Amazon are in a buying mood.

Keep an eye on ad tech upgrades to television, radio and other "old" media. We expect coming changes to make it much easier to target the customers you want.

Amazon's potential growth seems greater than that of Facebook or Google. Amazon will nearly double its online ad share by 2020, stealing from the two leaders. While Facebook and Googlerely on ads for nearly all their revenue, Amazon doesn't.

Note that governments are likely to be a headwind because new tech taxes are being proposed. The U.K., for instance, is planning a new levy on big tech firms.

U.S. ECONOMY

Job growth bounced back in Oct. from a hurricane-depressed level in Sept. 250,000 jobs were added as many folks jumped back into the labor force, driving up the participation rate. All major sectors contributed to the strong report.

There's nothing that stands in the way of a Dec. interest rate hike by the Fed.

Expect monthly job gains to slow to below 200,000 in 2019. Wage gains will continue to rise, to about 3.5% next year, as the unemployment rate falls further.

Though factories are still humming, more manufacturers are feeling jittery about rising trade risks and soaring production costs. Ford notes that the 25% tariff on steel and 10% duty on aluminum will slash profits by about $1 billion, for example.

Business spending will be healthy for the full year...about a 7% pickup, compared with 2017's 5.3% rise. But note the steep drop-off in the third quarter... a 0.8% annual rate, the worst since 2016...versus the second quarter's 8.7% rise.

For 2019, a leveling off or slight decline in business spending is in the cards as fears mount over trade wars, slowing global growth and rising raw material costs.

GLOBAL ECONOMY

China's economic momentum is fading as it battles several risky headwinds.

Third-quarter GDP growth slowed to a year-over-year rate of 6.5%, from 6.7% in the second quarter. Expect a 6.6% expansion for 2018, down from 6.9% last year.

GDP growth will ratchet down significantly in 2019...to 6.3%. Trade battles with the U.S. aren't the only problem. Beijing suffers from slowing domestic demand, a continuing outflow of foreign investment and tightening U.S. monetary policy.

Longer-term challenges could hinder China's rise, too. Its aging population will require more social spending, shrinking the funds available to invest domestically. Plus, key trading partners are trying to contest China's push into high-tech sectors.

The European Union and Italy are nearing a showdown on budget discipline. Italy's populist leaders want a hefty fiscal stimulus to stoke growth. But the spending would push its deficit up to 2.4% of GDP, which EU authorities refuse to accept. The EU has given Rome until mid-Nov. to develop another plan. Italy may back down, but it will still buck EU proposals and widen its budget deficit from last year's 1.8%.

The EU's fourth-largest economy faces anemic growth ahead. For 2018 and 2019, expect paltry economic expansion of just 1%, after growth of 1.6% in 2017.

The big worry is a lack of confidence in Italy's ability to repay its debts, which could spark big trouble for the EU. Italy's borrowing costs are already sky-high.

FINANCE

Banks will see dwindling returns from rising interest rates in coming months. In the past few years, banks have been boosting their profits as the difference between the rate they charged on loans and their borrowing costs steadily widened. Banks were quick to raise loan rates, but slower to move on what they paid on deposits.

Customers are hungry for yield on cash that has been sitting in accounts that pay no interest. Banks are now seeing an outflow of money from such accounts.

Several credit unions and online banks offer rates as high as 2%, far higher than the average yearly 0.09% rate on savings accounts. Some big banks pay even less.

Small-business lending is growing at a steady clip, with total commercial and industrial loans extended by U.S. banks up in Oct. about 6% from a year ago.

Small banks are leading the charge, with a beefier 12% increase in lending. They hold about half of small-business loans, even though they have only 17% of banking assets. Small firms rely on nearby small banks because very few of them accept small-business loan applications online. That gives the banks a natural edge.

Note that interest rates on small-business loans are rising. Premiums charged on riskier loans are heading higher, too, as are the costs for lines of credit.

Fintech companies in the payment industry are becoming bigger players. For example, PayPal and Square now use customer data to underwrite loans for smalls.

CONGRESS

Earmarks are poised for a comeback. Lawmakers think they can be trusted to again steer money to specific projects without lining their own pockets or those of donors, relatives, etc., which led Congress to ban the practice in 2011.

Top Democrats say they will reinstate the practice, which is almost as old as the country itself, if they control the House next year, but with restrictions: No funds for businesses. No anonymous, unclaimed requests. No midnight add-ins.

Democrats note that unprecedented legislative gridlock came with the ban: There is less incentive to compromise or take a tough vote without any sweetener, such as money to build a highway, repair a bridge or launch a program back home.

Many Republicans agree, especially top brass, President Trump included. But many conservative and watchdog groups call earmarks government waste. Whether earmarks return depends on enough House members voting to do so and keeping Trump on their side, or getting their Senate colleagues on board, too. Any two sides can push the holdout their way. If the House allows earmarks, and Trump will sign bills with them, why would the Senate deny itself the privilege? Conversely, if pork-laden bills can't pass the Senate or will be vetoed by Trump, why would House Democrats take the PR hit? Trump could be the swing vote.

ELECTIONS

President Trump is trying to make immigration the midterms' defining issue. He hopes to energize his voters as in 2016 and boost Republican turnout. The issue will help them win the Senate but put the House further out of GOP reach.

Being anti-immigrant doesn't play well with swing suburban women voters, exactly whom Republicans need to retain House control. It also motivates Latino voters in states where Democrats are targeting Republican senators: Ariz., Nev. and Texas. Trump thinks it's a risk worth taking. Many women will not vote for him regardless. But the issue can help Republicans win Senate seats in Ind., Mo., N.D. and W.Va.

FOREIGN POLICY

North Korea is hoping for a kinder, gentler Trump after the midterms. Pyongyang says it will curtail its nuclear program if the U.S. eases sanctions. North Korea hoped its leader's chemistry with Trump would eventually win it relief. But Trump has mostly pushed harder since his historic meeting with Kim Jong Un, despite ally South Korea's desire to reestablish economic ties with the rogue regime. Chinese and Russian circumvention of international sanctions can do only so much. Kim wants a modern economy for his destitute nation, which requires U.S. relief.

Another major arms control agreement with Russia will soon bite the dust. Inked in 2010, New START limits the tally of strategic warheads that can be deployed by Washington and Moscow. The Trump administration will likely let it expire in 2021. Trump is also pulling the U.S. out of a 1987 treaty because Russia hasn't honored it. The Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces pact is credited with easing Cold War tensions.

The worst-case scenario: A new arms race with both Russia and China.

The American-Chinese rivalry isn't heating up just on the trade front. Confrontation and fostering competition with Beijing is Trump's default position, which is creating new diplomatic and military standoffs, most evidently over Taiwan and the South China Sea. Trump is moving Washington closer to Taipei militarily, infuriating China, which considers the island a breakaway province, not a country. Past presidents walked a fine line, embracing Taipei without antagonizing Beijing.

Trump continues freedom-of-navigation exercises in the South China Sea to counter Beijing's dominance in the area, increasing the risk of direct conflict: Consider the near collision between American and Chinese warships operating there.

Expect more close calls as China tries to beat the U.S. in naval superiority.

HEALTH CARE

Another Obamacare tweak is in the offing, this one dealing with HRAs... health reimbursement accounts. Small businesses will benefit most, initially. Employers, starting with insurance plans kicking in after Jan. 1, 2020, can use HRAs to help workers buy insurance under the proposed Labor Dept. rule. Today's HRAs can be tapped only for actual medical expenses, not premiums.

The change should lead to more options for people employed by smalls. Many have just one plan choice or go outside their workplace for health insurance. Companies offering defined plans would also be allowed to give workers $1,800 extra to cover out-of-pocket expenses and premiums for "excepted" benefits, such as dental.

The Trump administration is tinkering at the Affordable Care Act's margins to give states more latitude in following the law as Congress deadlocks over changes. Waivers to deviate from the Affordable Care Act's standards will be easier to get. States won't have to prove as much to get an "innovation" waiver, paving the way for more Americans to buy plans that don't meet the law's coverage requirements. Such plans are cheaper and often chosen by healthy Americans, leaving sicker ones in plans with ever-increasing premiums and costs...de facto high-risk pools.

Expect lawsuits after the first waiver under the relaxed rules is granted.

As more insurers direct patients to specific doctors, hospitals and labs...

More people are receiving unwelcome "surprise" bills for services rendered by providers outside their insurance network, usually for an urgent condition. Some budget-busting examples: $109,000 for heart attack-related treatment; $17,850 for a urine test. Emergency patients often don't have the luxury of checking whether a service provider or doctor at an ER is in network before getting treated.

State lawmakers have noticed, and angry voters are pushing Congress for a federal fix. Calif. and N.Y. protect their residents the most from such bills. Twenty-one states offer some relief for patients socked with these unexpected charges. But self-funded plans, which cover 60% of workers, are regulated by federal law, putting pressure on Congress to come up with a national fix. Look for one next year.

AG

U.S. soybean growers can add Brazil's new president to their list of worries. Brazilian farmers were already their top competition. Now Jair Bolsonaro, their president-elect, has promised to roll back environmental restrictions on farming. If he can deliver on his promise to open more Amazon rain forest land to cultivation, Brazil could leap even further ahead of the U.S. as the world's top soybean exporter.

American farmers are already being squeezed by the trade war with China. Beijing is the world's largest soy importer, but it turned to Brazil even before tariffs were levied by the U.S. on Chinese goods, causing China to retaliate on ag goods.

Most U.S. farmers can expect mild temperatures from Dec. through Feb., says the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Admin. Arctic Alaska, tropical Hawaii, the Pacific Northwest and the Northern Plains have the best odds of warm weather. No region faces a colder-than-usual winter, the government's forecasters predict. The Farmer's Almanac disagrees. The folksy guide predicts a "teeth-chattering" winter.
